name: Kepler-1702
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-1702 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Kepler-1702 is a star with 0.85 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.73 times its radius. It is located NaN light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-1702 is known to have undefined exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Kepler-1702 system


Kepler-1702 b

Kepler-1702 b was discovered by the undefined observatory using the transit method. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Kepler-1702 b is 3.2117999999999998 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-1702 b is 1.602 that of Earth. At 3.2117999999999998 Earth masses, Kepler-1702 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-1702, which contains undefined planets and was discovered by undefined.
